sp.p: A thund'ring Lover, that deals his Oaths by dozens— By Priam I'll fit her for that: Hem— hem— let me see— ay, I have it— Mum Dick [Enter Timand: she comes— now boy prepare, 'tis a lovely Wench by Jupiter— Madam— by Ovid I've almost forget my Complement— but stay, I must salute her first— Madam, let the Cannon of my Sighs batter down the Walls of your Resolutions, that my Love may ride in Triumph through the Streets of your heart, and display the Colours of my sincere affections over the— Uds so, my Memory will betray me— over the— why Madam— why Madam, over your Beauty— I'm a Beau.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: An Eloquent declaration of Love I must confess, and spoke like a Man just arrived from the Siege of Namure.

sp.speaker: Dick.
sp.p: Uds so, Madam, why I came but to Town last night, or this morning early from the University, where we only fight for bloody Noses, or so, and scale the Walls of a stately Pye— 'tis a handsom Coat.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: And were your Cloaths made at the University? Sir, you look like a handsom Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Dick.
sp.p: No, Madam, my honourable Sir-father brought them ready-made in Long-Lane; he's a very Wise man, Madam, tho' I say't that shou'd not say't; and yet I know no reason why a man may not commend the Wisdom of his own Father.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: I presume he may be wise, for he has dealt little of his Wilt to his Son.

sp.speaker: Dick.
sp.p: O Lord, O Lord, your Ladiship is merry with your humble Servant— But uds so, I forget my thund'ring Complements: Madam, my heart (like Tinder) took fire from— what?— took fire from the first sparkle your fair Eyes darted upon me; by this Light I love ye; by this Right-hand I doat upon ye; by Plato and Aristotle— I dye for ye, and— the Wastcoat too is of an exact length.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Dye for me, Sir! Sure ye wou'd not rob the World of its best Jewel!

sp.speaker: Dick.
sp.p: Uds so, that's true, I'm handsom, and the World is pleas'd to esteem me, and so forth: but as I was saying, Madam, dye for ye— why, I'd fight for ye, and that's more, if ye consider I'm a Beau.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: How, Sir! wou'd Beaus rather dye than sight?

sp.speaker: Dick.
sp.p: Yes, Madam, he wou'd rather be kickt to death twenty times, than run to death with a small Sword once; but by Juno I'll box over a Hat with Samson for ye; and 'tis a bloody dog, Madam, I warrant him; why, he can handle a Drey-horse like a Paper-kite; I can dance too, Madam, Tal-la-ra, ta-fa-la—

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: Sister—

sp.speaker: Dick.
sp.p: Lincolns-Inn-Fields! by Vulcan I heard that.

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: And d'ye feel that? Imprimis, So much for ill manners. Ditto, to cure your madness.

sp.speaker: Dick.
sp.p: Uds so, your humble Servant, Sir; but by Ovid I don't love your Bills, tho' of few Articles; beat a Knight's Son! Uds so, the King shall hear on't, that he shall.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Are Sir Anthony's Daughters there?

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: Yes, I just now came from them, after my promise to return in six minutes.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Lead the way then, I'll follow— your humble Servant Sir, I hope you'll easily pardon that Affront the Gentleman put upon you; 'twas but a Jest, and Beaus, such as you are, commonly have such pretty Jests put upon them.

sp.speaker: Dick.
sp.p: Have they? Uds so, I'll never be a Beau again then; by Pan I courted very handsomly till that Rascal came in; I never shall forget his Impudence; I've a good mind now to send him a Challenge that I may cut his Throat civilly, like a modern Christian: but hang that Thought, Tyburn stares me in the face already; my Sir-father shall see him fin'd some hundreds of pounds, imprison'd till payment, and oblig'd to find bail for his good behaviour for the future; there wou'd be no living if there were not Law for such Rogues to bind them to the Peace.

sp.speaker: Choll.
sp.p: How now? where's my Niece?

sp.speaker: Dick.
sp.p: Niece!

sp.speaker: Choll.
sp.p: Ay, my Niece, Sir.

sp.speaker: Dick.
sp.p: By Ovid, as the Latin Saying is—

sp.speaker: Choll.
sp.p: I'll have none of your gabling strange stuff; I'll have nothing to do with Latin, no, not I; I say, where's Timandra? where's my Niece?

sp.speaker: Dick.
sp.p: Why there was a damn'd sort of a fellow, I think he's her Brother, at least he call'd her Sister; but every Woman may be so to him for ought I know.

sp.speaker: Choll.
sp.p: Well, and what of him? 'tis Ned; 'tis that young Villain, 'tis; and I'll be reveng'd, a knave: well, go on.

sp.speaker: Dick.
sp.p: And so, Sir, in he comes—

sp.speaker: Choll.
sp.p: It must be he, that's certain; the graceless young dog is still at a mischief.

sp.speaker: Dick.
sp.p: Uds so, it must be he then, for he was at a mischief upon sight.

sp.speaker: Choll.
sp.p: What, he?— whom d'ye mean?— but go on; what was he that came in?

sp.speaker: Dick.
sp.p: The Devil, Sir.

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p: Then 'twas Ned; 'twas my sweet Nephew; wou'd the Rogue were fairly hang'd; I must be rid of him, that's certain.— Well, and what say you to this, Young-man? what say you to't— To what?— Why, Sirrah; wou'd you pretend Ignorance? wou'd you— Yes Sir.— Yes, Sir! why look ye now friend, thus I'll teach you your duty, thus, Sirrah:— Mercy, Sir; I beg your Pardon: No mercy, no pardon you dog; I'll have every bone in your skin broke, sirrah; ay, I will— I will— you Rogue.

sp.speaker: Dick.
sp.p: Uds so; 'tis my safest course to remove my body from this place; 'tis a mad dangerous Family, and this Old Curmudgeon may be upon me with a new Bill of Imprimis's and Ditto's worse than the former: good buye, Sir, good buye— Uds so, let me see; I won't lose my Mistress, I'll follow to the Walks.

sp.speaker: Choll.
sp.p: Well, and what did the Rogue when he came in? what was't he said?— Why, this young fellow is gone too— Ned has prevail'd upon him to affront me; I'll go and seek the Rascal immediately, and if I catch him— a— Villian— a—

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: And so she bid me stay in this Room till she came— Was it not so?

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Whaut a deel Sir aur ye deef, shoe baud ye tarry here aun no gang awau till she caum benn.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Ben— but 'tis no matter; Willie, you must forget Scotland, and conform yourself to the Customs of England; learn our Accent.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Nau Sir, sheam fau me thaun, Customs o Englaun quo? Nau, nau, I'se do aus our Meast Johoan does pray for yer reformaution in good-bred Scots. Aus for yer accent Sir, I speak as Father Audaum spauke before me.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Then Adam spoke Scotch?

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Goad aun thaut he did, Sir.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: But to the purpose; to render you a compleat Servant, observe these three things; keep a due distance; speak little, and hear much.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Waud ye learn au Gentleman good manners?

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Why, dost thou pretend to quality?

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Be my Saul do I Sir, we Scotlaun Lauds aur au Gentlemen whun we come tea Englaun, thee Waulsh aun Irish aur neathing tea us for quality.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: That's good; but remember when the Old Gentlewoman enters, you must be silent as a Mute; 'tis she that helps me to the Rich Lady I told thee of.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Is't sua? thaun hear ye me Sir; I bid ye hea au care err thaun, he haud need o au laung Spoon thaut sups we the Deel, I waurren her au aul cheat now before I see her.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, why so Willie?

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: I kent au Maun o my Kintrey thaut mairied au aul wuther'd Wife thaut scantly cou'd tell whilk was the Stool and whilk her Arse whun she saut upon't, aun sometimes scaurted her Head instead o her Rump; the mairiagemauker swear't she was worth saux thousaun pund staurling, aun whun the Gentleman caum tea,— how muckle d'ye think waus o't, Sir?

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Two thousand pounds it may be.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Twa thousaun pund! wa be my saul shoe had na twa hunder Scots Marks, yer Englis Womaun will trust her person whaur she wonna trust her purse; she may be a rich Hereiss tea day, and deel a twa pennys hea the morn gin ye soud chance tea tauke her in between yer sheets.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Away fool, some blockhead has inso m'd the— Madam, I'm your humble Servant.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.p: Truly Sir I'm yours.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Be me Counscience I waurran her au honourable pick-pocket, for I dinna like thaut mumping face o hers.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.p: Well Sir, I profess your business has cost me a great deal of trouble; I've been thrice at her Lodgings, and gave a Guinea to her Maid: In a word, Sir, I've smooth'd the way, and to morrow you may begin an easy Journey to the Island of Love.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Be my Saul he haus na, a pair o Boots to ride in.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.p: I'm perswaded your Addresses won't be unwelcom, for I have given you a Character nothing inferior to your merit, and done every thing with that fervour, as if my good or bad fortune had been inseparably linkt to yours.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: The deel be fain o yer auld wheedling Snout.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Madam, I'm sensible of your kindness; and thus I express my self. Time, and future events, shall instruct me how much I'm your Debtor, and how to pay.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Haurk ye Sir, a word we ye in yer lug— keep yer Siller, I kent the Captain cheated out o au hunder Guineas by sick anither aul wutch aus this.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Whisper softly sirrah, otherwise ye ruin all.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Ay, ay, Sir— in our Kintry we never buy au meer till eans we ride upon her; pay Sir, I say, whun ye get the Lady aun be hang'd till her.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Sirrah— well, Madam, and when shall I have the happiness of waiting upon the fair Lady?

sp.speaker: De.
sp.p: Sir, she expects you to morrow, I'll be there my self in the forenoon, and 'tis convenient you shou'd come then— But, Sir, as I hinted to you at our first meeting, Fortune has been very unjust to me, and I'm weary of this trade of life; 'tis but reasonable then in serving others, I shou'd serve my self, and better my present circumstances in minding yours; the Lady has Ten thousand pounds, and I demand your Bond only for One; Truly I was never Covetous, and such a Service merits a greater reward, but the confidence I have in your generosity has taught me to use you kindly.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Madam, if I marry the Lady.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.p: O Lord, Sir, it shall be payable upon no other terms.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: To morrow you shall have it, in the mean time, Madam, believe me your humble Servant.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.p: Sir, I'm yours.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Aun the muckle deel thaunk ye, for yer well pay'd for yer pains; hark ye aul woman, I hope me Maisters siller sall burn the arse out o yer purse before night, an be me saul aun ye pit au trick upon him this bred Sword sall let the Sun and Moon shine through ye like a glass-window.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.p: Devil take the Rogue, he has almost frighted me out of my five Senses— but hitherto all is well, pray heaven that impudent Sot were out of the way, if he has any influence upon his Master, my plot on that side is ruin'd.

q.l: Mischief from small beginnings often flows,
But to a Mountain in a minute grows.

div.head: SCENE III.
Lincolns-Inn-Walks.
div.stage: Enter Sir John Winmore and Timandra.
[Capt. Bellair and Flora crossing the Stage.

sp.speaker: Sir Jo.
sp.p: I Won't, Madam, offer to measure the Extent of your power, or say I merit; but I'd have you remember, that the World cannot think it strange, that an unnatural parent weakens the bond of obedience, or that a violent passion shou'd be regarded.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Love it seems is a strange passion, that of a Lay-man makes an Ecclesiastick, and gives you a power to absolve me from that allegiance I owe to my Uncle and my Guardian— you'd have me come to Confession too, and say I lov'd.

sp.speaker: Sir Jo.
sp.p: If you did, I'd prove a kind Ghostly father, Madam, and enjoin more of the same Sin for a penance.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Thank ye, Sir; but I'm not resolv'd to try the experiment; 'tis not the way to ease the burden'd mind; for I'm inform'd Love begetteth Fear; that Lovers are always uneasy, and 'tis hard to set the heart again at liberty; is't so?

sp.speaker: Sir Jo.
sp.p: 'Tis, Madam.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: And you'd have me a Companion in misery.

sp.speaker: Sir Jo.
sp.p: No, Madam; for as in Love there are some pains, so there are pleasures to ballance them; one kind look from the mistress of our Vows, gives a Joy not to be equall'd; and to be belov'd is a heav'n beyond what dull Philosophers ever dreamt of.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: And if she prove inconstant?

sp.speaker: Sir Jo.
sp.p: 'Tis Hell.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Then why shou'd I run the hazard of a Love-damnation? Men, what e're they brag, are fickle as the Winds; just now they love, and in a moment hate; yet know not whence nor how this Change arrives, but lay the stress on Fate or Nature's weakness: Now if my easy heart shou'd doat on such a man, I've fool'd my self out of a present happiness, and miss'd the better heaven I aim'd at.

sp.speaker: Sir Jo.
sp.p: Your Charms. Madam, secure you from that misfortune; your Eyes wou'd melt the heart of a Savage, and turn his fury into love; no man cou'd ever love you less; for he who once knew you, wou'd with Joy continue your Slave; your words wou'd call back his wandering thoughts, and fix his nodding vertue to its center.

sp.speaker: Dick.
sp.p: — peeping— Uds so, here's fine work, my Mistress, by Ovid!

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Sir, if you please, we'll take a turn in the other Walk; Sir Anthony's Son, I find, has dogg'd me hither.

sp.speaker: Sir Jo.
sp.p: Every Walk is pleasant when Timandra's there.

sp.speaker: Dick.
sp.p: By Aristotle I'll place my self behind this Tree, and observe all— Mum, honest Dick, here comes another.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Hang me If I'm not sick with these canting words; Flame, Love, Passion, Eyes, and the like, I always thought a Soldier shou'd be master of more Courage than to languish for a Woman.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Who wou'd not sigh when so much beauty's nigh? Tantalus ne'er knew pains like mine; for I view a bliss infinitely beyond his, and find no cause, no hope for quick relief.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Wou'd you have me believe all you've said, and credit every story for a truth, without remembring your Complements are the effects of your good breeding? You love to show your parts, and that in time of peace; you can remove the thoughts of War's loud alarms, and play with that soft young thing call'd Love: Men are subject to more changes than Proteus ere knew shapes.

sp.speaker: Dick.
sp.p: By Ovid that's very fine. Sir-father, when he knows all will have a trusty house-keeper of ye.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Who cou'd feign a pleasure on the Rack, or think of Joys when roaring Seas gap'd wide, and threatn'd present ruin; much less cou'd I counterfeit a passion, or look and not love; to be insensible of so many Charms, wou'd argue stupidity; and to yield without terms to so sweet a Conqueror, speaks not want of Courage, but a generous Confidence.

sp.speaker: Dick.
sp.p: Uds so, the man is damnably in love.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Nay, now Captain you begin to be serious upon the matter, on my Conscience I cou'd afford my Pity.

sp.speaker: Dick.
sp.p: By Hercules, the Baggage begins to yield.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Pity, Madam, has often prov'd the Mother of Love; if you afford me that, you advance me one step to happiness.

sp.speaker: Dick.
sp.p: Poor man! by Apollo I pity him.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Not so fast, Captain; you'd march before Orders are given; 'tis pity meerly for your weakness: but come, hang this dull serious Love, I hate it; let's change the subject; I see Timandra in the other Walk, who doubtless desires my Company, if attacqu'd as I am.

sp.speaker: Dick.
sp.p: Uds so? So, she hates dull love; 'tis a smart plaguy Wench, all Mercury by Jupiter— but mum, Dick.

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: You know not, Madam, how far this Love-Caprice may hurry the Old man; your Father's humour is unaccountable, and every thing tends to my speedy ruin, if Melintha prove unkind.

sp.speaker: Dick.
sp.p: By Pan this is my Sister too; and this is the Rogue that kickt me before my Mistress; I begin to shake for fear; if he shou'd catch me, he'd serve me so again: I'll home and tell Sir-father all; by Juno I will.

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: Remember, Madam, Fortune do's not afford me the happiness every day of expressing all my fears, and your danger.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: To a Soul prepar'd no accident is of consequence; ill fortune comes with downy wings, flies gently by, and leaves no marks of sorrow in her flight.

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: I have not yet, Madam, attain'd to that height in Philosophy; and Love tells me, That without you I am for ever miserable.

div.stage: Enter Sir John Bellair, Timandra, and Flora.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Well, Sir, shall I wish you Joy of your good success? but I'm afraid my Sister is for the Uncle; she can digest (it may be) his infirmities for the sake of those conveniencies his money brings.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: I'm afraid, Madam, you've got such another Lover that has possest the passes of your heart, and bars admittance to the Enemy.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: A Warlike smile, Captain: But I begin to remember we came to hear prayers, and 'tis now past time: besides, I saw my Brother just now going out of the Garden, who will undoubtedly acquaint my Father with our devotion.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Wou'd you begin our Banishment so soon? 'tis but a minute since we began to be happy.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Necessity commands a Cessation of Arms; and, Captain, you must be broke.

sp.speaker: Sir Jo.
sp.p: Yet stay, fair Ladies, let these cool Shades persuade, if Lovers fail.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: No, Sir, 'tis fitting we change the Scene.

sp.speaker: Sir Jo.
sp.p: Well, Ladies, let us hope you inflict a present punishment to give a future ease; you're afraid too much of Joy shou'd sicken the Soul, and a long Scene of happiness pale the Appetite: Pain gives a certain relish unto Ease, and makes it always welcom to the mind.

q.l: Ned. Short Pleasures most of solid Joy impart;
And stole with hazard, most affect the heart.
Nature, to what's forbid, is still inclin'd;
And hopes of Sweets not known, mis-lead the mind.
Thus we run on, and eagerly pursue
What brings destruction, so it shews but New.
In Love there's no such Curse, give all to day;
We still Love on, our Joys know no decay,
And every hour to Pleasure shows the way.

div.head: ACT IV. SCENE I.
Lucy's Lodgings.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.p: YOur Fears, Madam, are groundless; he's already possest with an opinion of your Fortune; naturally credulous, and every way fitted for the Cheat; dissemble handsomly; seem not overpliant, yet give him store of hopes, because 'tis necessary you shou'd be speedily married.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I still doubt the success; Fifteen hundred a year is a noble prize; nor are such bubbles often to be found.

sp.speaker: Bet.
sp.p: You are sure he has so much, Madam.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.p: Yes, yes, Child, very sure, I know most of his Friends and Relations. One thing I had almost forgot; if his Servant shou'd be rude, take no notice on't; the fellow will rather speak nonsense than be silent; and I suppose his Master only keeps him for his diversion.

sp.speaker: Bet.
sp.p: E'gad, that Character has almost made me in love with him; I admire a talkative gabling fellow; 'tis a sign of wit, and only speaks his Judgment not yet ripe enough to bound it.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.p: Well, Madam, I hope you've consider'd the nature of this Service: Heaven forgive me, I'm forc'd to make many a sweet Lye for you.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: My gratitude prompts my memory; accept, Madam, of this small Compliment, and believe me a friend not so able as willing to serve you.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.p: Truly, Madam, I always had a good opinion of you, and am glad to find I have not deceiv'd my self— you remember the Bond of a thousand pounds.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Yes, Madam, and own my self oblig'd to pay a greater Sum.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.p: O, dear Madam, I'm o'rewhelm'd with your Bounty; wou'd to heav'n it were in my power to prefer you to a greater Fortune; your Soul speaks you made for great things— I've screw'd her finely up if he has any Estate: these two thousand pounds are good; if not, I'm in nothing poorer than I was— Well, Madam, shall I admit the Gentleman? he waits in the next Room.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: If you please, Madam.

sp.speaker: Bet.
sp.p: I swear, Madam, you look charmingly to day.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I ought to pipe with art; for if the fool can be whistl'd into the Net, I get a weighty draught— but stay, he comes.

div.stage: Re-enter Decoy, with Freelove and Willie.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.p: Swear you have often seen her; and, above all, urge her to a speedy marriage; delays are dangerous; and she's courted at this very time by a Rich Knight and two young Citizens of great Credit— Madam, this Worthy Gentleman, a friend of mine, has long ador'd you in secret, and my happy Stars having made me of your acquaintance; I'm bold to introduce him into the Temple, where he may worship his Goddess openly, and receive a reward suitable to his Zeal.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: The Gentleman, no doubt, knows better where to bestow his Services; and his Merit may prefer him to the possession of a greater Beauty, and a larger Fortune.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Be me Saul the Woman speaks very bonnily.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: My ambition ne'er taught me to aspire to a happiness beyond Lucinda's favour: I've long lov'd, but had not the liberty of Complaint allow'd me; and now I've got it, methinks I cou'd spend an age at her seet, and here for ever fix my self; gaze on that fatal beauty that has so long banish'd peace from my Soul, and almost forc'd me to despair.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Pray Sir rise.

sp.speaker: Do.
sp.p: That's well; the young Gentleman plays his part to my wish; there's a pleasure in dissimulation, not to be chang'd for that dull peace of mind which honesty and plain-dealing bestow upon their bewitcht Votaries.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: This is not the first time I presume you've kneel'd: Love e're now has been your Religion, and practice more than innate Zeal has taught you how to pray with so much ease.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: A goad I believe the Lass is a Saint.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: No, Madam, false fires can't be of use; and if I shou'd attempt to act the hypocrite, your Eyes wou'd teach me how to bow.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Deel be fain o me gin thea Englis Women wou'd not mauk au maun's mouth water at them, aun Good sin me new Maister is come au Sweethearting tea the Lady; I think Willie soud wooe her Gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: And cou'd you become a Convert? Renounce those principles which allow'd you so much liberty, and confine your self to the precise rules of marriage.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.p: Sir, I beg your pardon— [Whispers Lucy. Remember, Madam, he may by accident come to a true knowledge of your circumstances; when he begins to bite, draw with courage to secure him on the hook, for I know he'll leap at the gilded bait, when first it offers it self— Adieu sweet Sir— Pray, Madam, be kind to the Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: The deel ride up throw her aun down throw her, aun a haw-thornbuss at his tail, aun thaun she needs nea Physick.— Goad I can niver endure thea aulwives they look sua like wutches, aun she waur i my Kintrey she waud be burnt in a taurbaurrel presently.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Wou'd I renounce such principles, Madam? by heav'n all the pleasures of my life, whate're I doated upon; and if a darling Sin were riveted in my heart, with Joy I'd tear the loathsom thing from thence; dash it from me, and abandon all for the blessing of your Love, that wou'd give a happiness, and in it self contain more bliss than all the beggar'd earth cou'd give besides.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Hear ye me, Jo: how waud ye like me for yer good man? I hea a brau Estate in Scotland.

sp.speaker: Bet.
sp.p: Like you?

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Ay, that is, lye we me au yer days; warm me bed in au caul Winterneight, aun let me get bairns upon ye.

sp.speaker: Bet.
sp.p: Is that your way of Courtship in Scotland?

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Ay, aun this way tea be me Saul— we gang red wood upon bonny Lasses. 〈…〉

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Wuns thauts the way of your Englis Women, she is ready to cry out, whun ony body is near, haun her baut gin she waur at the bauck of au dike whaur deel au ean sees her, she waud be aus caum as au laum, and let a laud kiss his weam fou.

sp.speaker: Bet.
sp.p: But pray thee speak English, else 'tis impossible to comprehend thy meaning.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Goad aun I had ye au mile frea au house ye waud understaun me meaning for au thaut.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Cou'd you sit, and with a calm brow observe the dear Companions of your past liberty roving after new Loves? wou'd you not flutter in your Cage and wish for freedom; envy those who rang'd through open air, and curse the hour that fool'd you into prison?

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: No, Madam, I'd view securely men in Tempests tost, pity the weary and misguided Travellers; and when I saw them tracing Danger's road, in search of Joys that vanish as soon as got, I'd shrink up in silent gladness, and bless my kinder stars that gave me wealth and happiness at home; I'd bid them be wise, and learn to love from me; run quick for safety to some constant Fair, whose charms give ease from all their labours past.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Now deel tauke me gin me Master does na wooe aus bonnily aus I waud do me sell, only he forgets tea kiss her— Hear ye, Sir, tauke her in yer arms this way, aun be me saul shoe wull grow sua tame, ye may lead her tea the Kirk in au string, she wull gaung wood toe be mairied upon ye.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Sirrah— Madam, I hope you'll pardon this rudeness.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I love to see the fellow in that antick garb; it puts me in mind of the old World, when Cloaths were used for Necessity, not Ornament.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Whaun I was in me ain Kintrey, Maudam, the Minister's Wife said I waus the bonniest Laud in au her good man's parish.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Did she?— I love the humours of strangers.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Maudam, aun yea hea au mein tea marry me insteed o me maister, be me saul I wull tauke ye presently, I waud na let a bonny Lass rin wood for waunt o me.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: This, Madam, is intolerable Impudence— to your distance, Sirrah.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Ay Sir, whaut's the matter we ye now? ye look like a Minister whun he has newly lost his Baunifice.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Have you got a Mistress, Willie, since you came to England?

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Nau, Madam; baut I hea gotten ean here aun she aun I caun agree, we may come tea confirm the bargain between a pair o blankets.

sp.speaker: Bet.
sp.p: And what wou'd you think of making the bargain there, and confirming on't afterwards? I've a Maidenhead to dispose of, I assure ye.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Wau thaun we sall save the expences o'Kirk-fees, aun make the bar gaun like our for-bearers; I sall gang in to ye aun be acquainted we ye and su● forth, we cau thaut only playing a tune without a prelude.

sp.speaker: Bet.
sp.p: Ay, but Willie, 'tis necessary the Church shou'd give us liberty to play, else we may come to pay too dear for our Musick.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: You see, Madam, they have come already to Articles; I can propose none, but I've a heart at your service, I give it, ne'er to be recall'd; for tho' your powerful Charms forc'd me to make the gift, yet my consent soon follow'd; my Judgment confirm'd it, and it will stand good in law.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I'm afraid, tho' it were seal'd and deliver'd in the Church, you wou'd find some corner to sculk in, and pretend to other terms; swear the delivery was conditional, and you gave it with a prospect of possessing another to supply the want of your own— but however, my modesty bounds my words, yet I'm willing my Eyes shou'd express my thoughts, and let you know your addresses are— not— unacceptable.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: I've no way left to express my Joy; Silence speaks my Soul o're-charg'd with sudden happiness; and he who loves like me, must court in dumb show; may all your hours be a continued scene of gladness, like that which reigns at my heart; and may each minute of your life produce new Joys, that when you have run through all the pleasures this world can beflow, death may steal upon you like a gentle friend, that comes to wa●t you to a better shore— but rather than be troublesome to her I love, I chuse to inflict a short banishment upon my self, tho' I go with all the pains of an absent Lover— Madam, your humble Servant.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Aun whaut say ye tea me before I gaung away?

sp.speaker: Bet.
sp.p: Why nothing, follow your Master.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Aun my Master be in au great haist, he may stay au we bitt. Aun he aun his Lass hea made a bargain sua his nau Wulle too.

sp.speaker: Bet.
sp.p: Come, pray thee be gone, thou art troublesome.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Be goad aun ye sall see my bauckside presently, troublesome quo; thau't aun Englis Woman's breeding aun he haunget till her— [to Lucy. Madam, fair ye weil, aun ye hea any thing tea say tea me, ye wull see me whun I come back again.

sp.speaker: Bet.
sp.p: Well, Madam, our affairs have put on a handsome face to day; Fortune begins to smooth her brow, and grace us with her smiles— 'tis a lusty handsome Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: The present prospect shows a long train of coming Joys; Heav'n begins to smile upon me, since I abandon'd my old sin of doating; and if I succeed in this innocent cheat, I shall ne're tempt its goodness more.

q.l: None ere grew vertuous but by just degrees,
Nor trac'd the road to happiness but with ease.
Custom a second nature oft has prov'd;
And 'tis with labour and regret we're mov'd,
To quit those darling pleasures once we lov'd.

div.head: SCENE II.
Sir Anthony's House.
div.stage: Enter Sir Anthony Chollerick and Dick.

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: HAve a minute's patience; I say, Neighbour, all is not lost that is in hazard, as the saying is.

sp.speaker: Dick.
sp.p: Ay, ay, Sir-father says very well; I had a Latin Proverb to the same purpose, but by Seneca I've forgot it.

sp.speaker: Choll.
sp.p: Well, well; I've done, I've done; but that impudent young Jilt— but I've done. I'll say no more.

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p:
Your House-keeper will set all to-rights again; she shall guard them to night, and prepare things necessary for this great occasion, that Melintha
may be married like the Daughter of Sir Anthony Addle; your Niece shall lye in my house too, and the morrow's Sun shall see an alliance confirm'd between our Families, which nothing less than death shall dissolve.

sp.speaker: Dick.
sp.p: But uds so, I forgot to tell you how the Rogue kickt me before my Mistress, and wou'd have done the same again in the Walks, had I not been oblig'd to my heels that brought me off unseen.

sp.speaker: Choll.
sp.p: How— O Lord! that Rogue, I profess, will make me mad.

sp.speaker: Dick.
sp.p: Make him mad, Sir father? by Venus he's mad already.

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: That was a—

sp.speaker: Choll.
sp.p: Ay, was it not?— a Villain— I knew he wou'd be graceless; why some months ago I found him in his Closet a writing of a Play; well, he's a Rogue, a Dog, a Scoundrel, a Rake, and will dye a Beggar— but no more on't; only I'm sure my Brother Sir Thomas Chollerick ne'er begot this limb of Satan.

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: But as I was saying, that was a—

sp.speaker: Choll.
sp.p: Ay, that's certain, he'll ne'er escape the Gallows; I've known that young— I'll say no more— I profess I've known the Rake come home at night with as many Filders, Hautboys, Starving Poets, and red-fac'd Bullies— Why the Rascal has come home with as many empty bellies at his back, as his Majesty's Huntsmen with all his Dogs after him; and then a Surloin of Beef, or a Cold pye— why 'twas no more amongst them than a penny-worth of Cheese to a lusty Porter; but I'll make him a—

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: Sincerely speaking, I begin to show my weakness, my blood will rise, and I say your Nephew—

sp.speaker: Choll.
sp.p: My Nephew's a Rogue, let him be damn'd for an unlucky— he tempts me to forget my self; and I profess I'm afraid I said too much; did I swear, or not? ha!

sp.speaker: Dick.
sp.p: No, no; but by Bacchus—

sp.speaker: Choll.
sp.p: No matter, no matter, the Rogue wou'd provoke a Saint to wrath; but I'll be reveng'd, I will; he shan't o're-rule me, a—

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: I say your Nephew shall be punish'd by Law; such affronts as these derogate from the honour of my house; and 'tis fitting a—

sp.speaker: Choll.
sp.p: And had the Impudence to serve him so beneath my roof: but no more on't, the Knave shall pay dear for all.

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: Sincerely speaking, Neighbour Chollerick. I think you are a Mad-man, and I ought to have the liberty of Speech allow'd me in my own house.

sp.speaker: Dick.
sp.p: Uds so, Sir-father, and in your own Cause too.

sp.speaker: Choll.
sp.p: Cause, as the Young man says? why look ye now, the Rogue has given me cause to turn him loose into the World, and I'll do't I warrant ye.

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: Ingenuously I'm incens'd, I can hold no longer; I say, Neighbour, hear me, or turn out of my house; I'm resolv'd to be master of my own family.

sp.speaker: Choll.
sp.p: You say right, I've done, I've done.

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: Well then, I say, a Justice of the Peace shall take Cognizance of this affair— but here comes your Houses-keeper.

div.p: Madam, having taken—

sp.speaker: Choll.
sp.p: Why look ye, d'ye see, we have sent for you to—

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: Body o'me, the man will never let me speak— having, Madam, taken—

sp.speaker: Dick.
sp.p: Uds so, say on Sir-father.

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: Why sincerely I shall never begin at this rate; having, Madam, taken into our Consideration the extravagant inclinations of our Children, and those who respectively depend on us, and maturely consider'd the sad Consequences that may attend such courses; and that some who have never shown themselves affectionate to our Government, signaliz'd themselves yesterday in seducing the hearts of our Daughters: It is the will and pleasure therefore of your Master, that by vertue of the authority now given and repos'd in you.

sp.speaker: Dick.
sp.p: Uds so, Sir-father speaks like a Judge.

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: For the future prevent all such unlawful courses and methods, that no Correspondence may be held between them hereafter; for we are firmly resolv'd by stratagems and new politicks to keep these cunning Gentlemen from the possession of these Lands to which they aspire.

sp.speaker: Dick.
sp.p: Uds so, Sir-father, that was a thund'ring Speech; sure the Rogues will never have the Impudence to make any more addresses— my Sisters will never accept of them.

sp.speaker: Choll.
sp.p: Look ye d'ye see, without further ceremony stay here all night, and look to the young women; my Neice is already here, and to morrow shall be married; in the mean time 'tis fitting we shou'd provide Counsel; but let that be your task; and mine, to procure License.

sp.speaker: Dick.
sp.p: By Ovid here's fine work, we shall all go over head and ears in Matrimony.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.p: Sir, I'll obey your Orders punctually; and to save you the expences of Coach-hire, I know of a Lawyer, who will wait upon you when call'd, and do the business for a Glass of Wine, without the help of a Fee to sweeten it: I'm acquainted too with a Nonconformist Parson, who has a wonderful dexterity in joining hands and hearts.

sp.speaker: Choll.
sp.p: That's good, that's good; be sure you speak to them.

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: Well, Neighbour, let's go, every thing shall be in readiness; I'll have a new Suit too, that I may grace the Nuptials with my gaiety; they shall go no more to the Walks.

sp.speaker: Dick.
sp.p: In statu quo prius you mean Sir-father; for if I live, they shan't all carry their Maidenheads with them; if they do—

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: Body o' me, the boy grows wanton— but 'tis no matter, a month or so will tame him; I was young my self, and can remember these things still— Dick come along Dick.

sp.speaker: Choll.
sp.p: Good b'ye, I'll see you again in an hours time.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.p: So this has happen'd to my wish now the Ladies are committed to my charge; and since 'tis mine to provide Counsel, 'tis in my power to advance all their Joys: let me dye 'tis a sweet adventure, and I'm resolv'd to build my fortune so strongly (for that will make them liberal) upon the necessities of the young people, that the frowns of the old can never shake me; 'tis a good foundation, ay, and here come materials fit for the Structure.

div.p: Oh, Ladies! here have been strange doings; Sir Anthony and Mr. Chollerick are acquainted with all that pass'd yesternight in Lincolns-Inn; the young Philosopher has play'd the Conjurer, and infor'd your enemies of all your designs.

sp.speaker: Mel
sp.p: No, he turn'd spy it seems, but the old man will soon forget it.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.p: Ay, but Madam, you're condemn'd, and you too Madam; to morrow's markt out for Execution-day, and I'm your Jaylor by special orders from the higher powers— there's no way left to escape.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: And I'm in prison, but not condemn'd I hope.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: And pray thee, Decoy, wilt thou not admit of Bail.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.p: O dear Madam, by no means, in cases of High-treason there's no such thing after Judgment given.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Sure thou hast not so much of cruelty in thy Nature; to wink at small faults, speaks thee tender-hearted; a quality inherent to woman.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.p: Self-preservation bars the thoughts of mercy; and if the Prisoners escape, the Keeper may shift for himself, or stay for certain punishment.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: I'm sorry my Judgment and Experience did not sooner inform me of my Error— What d'ye think of this, Madam? I hope 'twill buy off my Chains, if it do not purchase Freedom.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.p: Truly, Madam, your generosity staggers my strongest resolutions.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Her zeal for my Father's arbitrary Government begins to cool, Sister; ply her with such another argument as mine, and she'll throw off all Obedience, and become a rebel like our selves, and fly (tho' not directly) in the face of all Authority.

sp.speaker: Mell.
sp.p: If this can tempt her, She's of our party.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: And this shall help to confirm the Convert in her new tenets, that obedience is an effect of Interest, and 'tis madness to continue allegiance when that tye is broke, or better secur'd with the Enemy.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.p: As I live, fair Ladies, you've o'recome me, you've Justice on your side; 'tis impossible to raise any objections against such powerful arguments— Who's this?

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Be my Saul this is the aul Jaude thaut mumped me new Maister out o his Siller— Maudaum, I hea brought ye an Letter frea Sir John— me bonny Lasses how d'ye do, yer Sweethearts aur stauning sighing in the causy, aun look like sua mony clipped sheep; a goad I believe they wull gang dauft for want o ye.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.p: Run Ladies into the other room, I'm but Deputy-Governess, and 'tis not safe to meet with your Lovers, unless I were assured of my Superior's continued absence.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Well, Madam, remember the weight of our past arguments, and let no new accident divert your resolution.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.p: Tell the Gentlemen their humble Servant Decoy waits to receive them with all humility.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Ay, ay, baut ye soud nea hea sent awau the women thaun, for be me saul they wunnau gaung out o the house till the be as sure o them aus me faither was o me mither that night Wulle was begotten upon her.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.p: Now for another Cast of my Art; for that Match-maker knows not her own trade, who fails at any time to make them pay for their hopes; if we are not courted with as many Guineas as their Mistresses with Oaths, we manage amiss, and lose our own fortunes, because we have too much of modesty— Gentlement, I'm your humble Servant.

div.stage: Enter Sir John, Captain, Ned, and Willie.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: I hope, Madam, you know our business.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Goad aun thaut she does, for I tellt her o't.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.p: Alas, Sir, I know too much; for my want of power to serve you in this affair brings my grief.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: You jest, Madam; sure 'tis impossible you shou'd be insensible of our Common Calamity.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.p: O Lord, Sir! I'm a sharer in all your Fortunes, and wou'd relieve you from pain with all my heart; but—

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: You'd run no hazard to serve your friends— Damn her, she must be brib'd, she's like a new Coach-wheel, often greas'd before she can run smooth.

sp.speaker: Sir. Jo.
sp.p: Can't this persuade?

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Madam, accept of this small Complement.

sp.speaker: Nod.
sp.p: And I humbly offer these few Yellow-boys to procure your assistance.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Wa Sirs, wa Sirs: are ye reed wood tea gea awau yer siller— wa goad the Lasses aur na saunted, ye may get them for the half of this trouble.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.p: I protest sincerely, Gentlemen, I know not what to say t'ye— but in spite of danger, you shall once more be happy by my means— I'll lead the way.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: By our Money he wou'd have said.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Wuns cau ye this wooing Alamode! this is an Englis trick indeed, a maun mun gee siller for an sight o his Sweetheart, aus we do in Scotlaun tea see au dancing Meer, or au Eape playing on the Bagpipes.

div.stage: [Goes off. [The flat Scene opens, and discovers Sir John, Captain, Ned, Willie, Timandra, Melintha, Flora, and Decoy: The Captain and Flora advance, and Wilie after them.]

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: All danger ought to be despis'd when Love has any share in the action; the prize before us should give Courage, and spur us on to Victory.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Why you're at your old similies again, Captain, action, prize, and victory; sure you imagine to your self a formal siege when you attack a Lady; I hope you don't muster your Company in the Tavern, and ●et the Bottles in battle-array instead of men.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Be me Soul he threw ●an o thea men at my head hauf au yeir seen.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: I confess, Madam, a Lady is a strange Enemy; for a Soldier finds it often more difficult to get access to her Soul, than to throw in provisions to a Town besieg'd.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: A goad my Maister aunt like your Ladiship wull storm a Fort we ony laud in au Lonon aun ye wull gee him a Commission.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Sirrah— ha, who's this, Madam?

sp.speaker: Choll.
sp.p: Thieves! Thieves! Thieves!

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Farewel, Captain; remember, a Town once lost has been regain'd.

div.stage: [Flora goes off, and the other Ladies in haste.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: How, Sir!— draws—

sp.speaker: Choll.
sp.p: Murder! Murder! Murder!

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: O Lord, I'am murder'd auready; whaut a deel brought me in tea this unlucky house aun 〈◊〉 sua now?

div.stage: Enter Sir Anthony and Sevant● with long Staffs, and Dick with his Sword drawn behind them, and walking backwards.

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: Body o' me, I say, secure the Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Dick.
sp.p: Uds so, knock 'em down; by Jupiter we shall all be murder'd.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Be me saul I'm a dead man; I wull hide me sell beneath this Table.

sp.speaker: Sir Jo.
sp.p: Come, let's force a passage to our selves.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: With all my heart.

div.stage: [They fight, and the Servants give way on each side.

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: And mine.

sp.speaker: Choll. Ned, Ned,
sp.p: Good boy, thou won't murder thy Uncle— O Lord!

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: I'm dead.

sp.speaker: Dick.
sp.p: By Vulcan so am I— knock 'em down, I say knock 'em down; Sir-father shall keep ye all from harm.

sp.speaker: Choll.
sp.p: Knock 'em down— why look ye now d'ye see, they are all gone. Ah that Rogue my Nephew shall be hang'd— a dog, a—

sp.speaker: Dick.
sp.p: Uds so Sir-father, I scowr'd 'em off, Rogues, Pimps, Panders, and Scoundrels; by Aristotle I've frighted them; this Sword did execution; but I'll put it up, because my Uncle that is to be, is here.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Be me Saul I waud I waur i' me ain Kintrey again, Englaun soud niver hea the honour o'me presence aun they waud mauke a King o'me.

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: Oh, oh, I faint, help me forwards; I'll lean upon this Table, and recover breath.

div.stage: [As he goes to rest upon it, Dick o'returns it.

sp.speaker: Choll.
sp.p: Look ye now, d'ye see; whow have we got here? another Rogue! the house is full of them, wou'd I were fairly out on't.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Gaung awau thaun, whau au deel hauds, au grip o'ye— agoad I believe me Maister has left me here to be hangett.

sp.speaker: Dick.
sp.p: Stay, stay, let me alone with him; this is Sinon that was to open the wooden-horse, and let out all the Grecians.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Be me Saul the Englis-men will hea na mercy on me, I fin thaut; baut aun I cou'd get safe to the door, they soud na ou lay saut I me arse the night again.

div.stage: [Offers to run, and Dick stops him.

sp.speaker: Dick
sp.p: Uds so, not so fast, you shall leave your head behind ye.

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: Body o'me, the boy Dick is bloodily dispos'd.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Be goad sein na better may be, I wull fight for my head furst— I'll gaur ye au loap like Dinmonts— I wull let ye ken whaut it is tea anger a Scotlaun maun.

sp.speaker: Dick.
sp.p: O Lord! O Lord! I'm murder'd.

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: And so are all of us.

sp.speaker: Choll.
sp.p: Oh, oh, oh.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: The muckle deel mauke oare ye waud na be at rest till I dous'd yer doublets for ye; baut now I hea learnt ye mainers we this bred Sword, I'll gang and seek my new Maister.

sp.speaker: Dick.
sp.p: Uds so, Sir-father, this was a damn'd bloody Dog.

sp.speaker: Choll.
sp.p: Look ye now, I see no heads he has left behind him but our three Calves-heads.

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: No matter, 'tis a mercy he has left those: but where's Madam Decoy, Body o'me? Alderman Chollerick, I say your House-keeper is naught, and has betray'd her Trust.

div.stage: Enter Decoy in a seeming amazement.

sp.speaker: Choll.
sp.p:
Ay, ay, here she is; look ye now, look ye now, you was brought
here to a fine purpose; you was, a very fine purpose; but 'tis no matter— I'll be reveng'd one day or other.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.p: Heav'n knows Sir I knew nothing of the matter till just now I met the lewd fellows in the streets: I was at Mr. Delay the Lawyer, and Mr. Sigher's the Nonconformist— God knows I did it purely for the best, and stole out on foot to save expences.

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: Sincerely speaking, I believe the Woman is innocent.

sp.speaker: Dick.
sp.p: By Mercury I believe so too.

sp.speaker: Choll.
sp.p: I've done then, Madam: look ye, look ye to your charge: Farewel, for I've not yet dispatch'd the business of this day.

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: Come along, Dick; come along.

q.l: The fighting Fool gets Scars; but he that's wise
Preserves his Skin, and from known Danger flies:
Honour's an empty Sound, admir'd by those
Who have no Brains, or no Estate to lose.
While those by Fortune blest, look-wisely on,
And see this airy Mistress lost or won;
But without Danger to be got by none.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.p: WIth difficulty I've got out of doors, but the old Lover and the young have reliev'd me from my post; my three principal Lovers are uneasy on both sides, and from the Gentlemen I've receiv'd fifty Guineas this morning to compleat their cure; nor have I forgot to squeeze the young Ladies, even to their very Jewels; I can expect no more than I've already got by both parties; for shou'd I now baulk them in this Intrigue, they'd never trust me again: I've worn them almost threadbare, and 'tis time to lay them aside; I'll give therefore the finishing stroke to this plot, hitherto so well manag'd, and show my self honest, because I can find no profit by a longer delay. As for Mr. Freelove's marriage with Lucy, 'tis easy, their mutual fears will force them to a speedy obedience, and I'll enjoin an immediate conjunction between them. Mum, here he comes; I'm glad I have his Bond and hers; 'tis a large Fee for a She-Counsel— Sir, your humble Servant.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: I've punctually obey'd those Orders you sent me this morning; every thing is in readiness, and I wish the young Lady may—

sp.speaker: De.
sp.p: O Lord Sir, doubt it not, I've div'd into her inmost thoughts; but the business must be speedily dispatch'd, for her friends begin to pry into't.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Begoad Sir I wull feght we au her freins, and gar 'em gee conseut, wa I clawed off three Englis-men yesterday.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.p: Sir, I beg your pardon, the Lady enters— Madam, for your own sake embrace this opportunity which now offers it self; his friends are advertis'd of his design, and study to break off the Match— Now I've brought ye once more together, I know ye both love, and it were a sin to part ye, 'tis hard to please every body, and I'd have you join for ever, lest you meet no more.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Ay do sua my bairns, agoad I wull daunce at yer breidall.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Madam, yesterday you taught me to hope; to day brings new alarms, and an hours delay may bring me years of pain.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Wuns I say tauke him, tauke him, Madam, he will set yer Water-mill au gaunging.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.p: Pray, Madam, consider the Gentleman's violent Love, that he hunts not for a Fortune; and that he prefers your Esteem to his Interest.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Haud yer chaunts togither in au mischanter t'ye, aun let the Lauss aunswer for her sell; agoad I waurran, she knes whaut's good for her.

sp.speaker: Bet.
sp.p: Do, Madam; pity the Gentleman; I'll swear 'tis a shame to be so hard hearted.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Be me Saul thea women hea na mair power cur their tongues than they hea our their tails, aun thauts no muckle.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I own I'm powerfully assaulted, and modesty only detains me from saying I— Love.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Now be me Saul she says very weill.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Then thus I render thanks for the mighty blessing; my heart scorns its narrow bounds, and seeks for greater Joys than e're it knew— let me kiss this fair hand, and in that (not words) express my transports.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Hout, hout, Sir, kiss her bonny mouth, whaut a deel wull she be the better o' yer kindness aun ye do na mair nor thaut till her.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.p: 'Tis rarely acted, they are at no small pains to cheat one another; and both of them dissemble with as much pleasure, as a lusty Frier wou'd eat a fat Capon after a tedious Lent— Well, Madam, a thousand blessings attend you; believe me, I cou'd weep for gladness to see you thus far on the way to a happi●●r state of life— Compleat the Gentleman's Joys, for 'tis a Sin that two such loving hearts should be so long divided.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Speak, Madam, speak; he that like me is blest only by halves in that uncertain state, finds certain pains; the present pleasure's lost in hopes of more, and fears of future events rack the Soul.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.p: Sure Madam your heart yields.

sp.speaker: Berty.
sp.p: Come, Madam, lay aside that confounded modesty invented by old decay'd Beauties to torment the young and bar 'em of those pleasures of which their envious age permitted them not to be sharers— the Gentleman's addresses are very honourable.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Ay, ay, Sir, tauke her silence for a grant, come awau tea the Kirk we her, she wull gaung we good wull I'se waurran her.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I can be no longer obstinate, I'll yield a blind obedience, and ●ye my self for ever Freeloves.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Goad aun fair fau her for her kindness aun en sua.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Nay, now my Joys are no more to be exprest.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Nau deel be fain o' me gin our lairds Sister whir I waus born in Scotlaun waud said sua mickle tea au young maun aun she soud never be maired in her days. Baut a goad for au that she can play in the dark we young meast Chaplain, au caunting young loun as is in au the kirk again.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.p: Truly, Madam, I can hold no longer, excess of Joy brings forth my tears: pray heav'ns bless you, you are a lovely couple as ever I put together in my life.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Whaut au deel ails the auld wife now, kens ony body that?

sp.speaker: Dec.
sp.p: Well, well, get ye in together, Betty knows where the Parson lives; my business calls me hence, for this day is Love's Jubilee, and the little Boy is merry: but come let me first see you into the other Room.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I'll obey, Madam— I am made for ever.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Run laus will ye rin aun get the Minister tea mairy me Maister, aun get anither to mairy me.

sp.speaker: Bet.
sp.p: Well, well; Willie, I'll think upon't.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Do sua me Jo— now Ise gaung in, aun wait upon me maister, whau kens baut I may get the leg of a Capon tea me wauden dinner, shame fa me gin I hea-na mickle need o't, for I fin a civil war i me guts, aun my puddings are gaunging tea eat an aunother.

div.head: SCENE II.
Sir Anthony's House.
div.stage: Enter Sir Anthony, Dick and Chollerick.

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: So boy, look brisk, body o' me, 'tis a handsome Lad.

sp.speaker: Dick.
sp.p: Uds so, Sir-father, I'll make ye a Grand-father in nine Months.

sp.speaker: Choll.
sp.p: Look ye, friend, that part is mine, I was born before you, was I not?

sp.speaker: Dick.
sp.p: By Jupiter I hope ye wou'd not lye with my Wife.

sp.speaker: Choll.
sp.p: That's right, that's right, I invited some of my Friends to be merry with us to night.

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: And I have invited Mr. Caperer the Dancing master, and Chorus the Musick-master, the poor Rogues owe me some money, and I'm resolv'd they shall dance and sing it out this night; charges upon such occasions are inevitable— have you invited your Nephew?

sp.speaker: Choll.
sp.p: A Rogue, a Villain, I'll see him hang first; invite him! why look ye now, d'ye see;—

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: I say, Neighbour, abandon your wrath, let not your passion banish Reason, I am not desirous of the young man's Company.

sp.speaker: Choll.
sp.p: That's true, that's true, I forget my self.

sp.speaker: Dick.
sp.p: Uds so, I think you have always a damnable memory.

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: Call my Daughters and Mr. Chollerick's Niece, are the Lawyers come? is the Parson ready, and every thing in order?

sp.speaker: De.
sp.p: Sir I've forgot nothing.

sp.speaker: Choll.
sp.p: Call them in.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.p: Yes, Sir.

sp.speaker: Dick.
sp.p: Uds so, you might have put on a new suit, Uncle; that is, to be for a new wise.

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: Body o' me, that's true, 'tis an undecent garb for a Bridegroom.

sp.speaker: Choll.
sp.p: That's nothing: look ye, I love my money, and therefore wou'd not disburse it for trifles; I'll give my Wife a Complement of five hundred broad-pieces in an imbroidred purse; your vain Coxcombs, who spend all on Plays, Paints, Persumes, and long Wiggs, have no such gifts to bestow; they bring a pair of lac'd breeches to the beds-side, but not one farthing in 'em.

div.stage: Enter Timandra, Flora, Melintha and Decoy.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.p: Ladies, be of good courage, I've a plot will save you all, though on the brink of ruin.

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: Come, Daughter, let me see no signs of Sorrow in your face, I have provided for you a wealthy husband— Dick, bear up to the young Lady.

sp.speaker: Choll.
sp.p: Look, d'ye see, young woman? look kindly upon him, he's a handsome youth; do't, or expect my immediate displeasure; turn out o' doors, run mad for want, and go to Bedlam at last for shelter, you shall, you— but I'd almost forgot my self again, temptation is a dangerous thing, and all men are wise till they have occasion to shew their parts.

sp.speaker: Dick.
sp.p: Uds so, Sir-father I'l speak to her— Madam, you and I are like to be good friends ere to morrow morning; by Jupiter if I had you— I know where I wou'd be.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: At the University again it may be, Sir.

sp.speaker: Dick.
sp.p: The University! No, by Aristotle I'm for no such Journeys, I'll teach you Natural Philosophy here in London.— Uds so, but Marriage is a damn'd thing, that allows me but one Scholar; my Sir-father (when he was a young man) had forty, I warrant him.

sp.speaker: Enter Sir
sp.p: John Winmore, Capt. Bellair, as Lawyers; Ned Chollerick like a Noncon-Parson, and Decoy.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: We are now fairly in, Madam, and upon you we rely for a fairer Exit.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: I hope the old Gentlemen know us not in our new Shapes.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.p: Leave all to my management, and the event shall answer your wishes.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: 'Tis he, Mars, appears in Masquerade, and shines throughout musty black.

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: Gentlemen, you're welcome.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.p: Sir, I've brought two Councellors.

sp.speaker: Choll.
sp.p: Very well, very well, I can read Noverint universi in their foreheads at this distance— are the Papers ready?

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Yes, Sir— are you ready, Madam?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Before you make a good Council.

sp.speaker: Sir Jo.
sp.p: Am I happy, Madam? or doom'd to misery? I am a bad Lawyer when my Eyes must plead my Cause, and I'm oblig'd without Arguments to refer all to my Judge?

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: The adverse-party have authority on their fide, which may be much to their advantage.

sp.speaker: Dick.
sp.p: Uds so, Sir-father, 'tis a Jolly young Parson: shall—

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: Presently boy thou shalt be a married man.

sp.speaker: Dick.
sp.p:
By Ovid, Sir-father, I begin to grow proud on't, my head stands just now as stiff as if the marks of honour already press'd my brow. Marriage
is a notable trick, that in a minute, of a raw boy makes a grave solid lump of a man.

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: Is the young Divine, or the old Merchant, the happy Lover? you see love has transform'd me into a new man; I run the risque of Church-censure too in pretending to marriages without Orders; but I hope that in this Cloak (the cover of many infirmities) 'twill be easy to escape the inquisition.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: Yes, if I am Sinner enough to digest a hypocrite, and take up with a meer shew of Sanctity and Religion.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Sir, a Gentleman below-stairs waits for ye.

sp.speaker: Dick.
sp.p: By Vulcan that's some University-acquaintance or other, I'll bring him up, and shew him how happy I am to be in a few minutes.

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: Now, Gentlemen, let's see the papers— Mr. Sigher, pray sit down a little, for the Law must be still before the Gospel— what's this? read the Contents.

sp.speaker: Choll.
sp.p: Ay, ay, read the Continents.

sp.speaker: Sir Jo.
sp.p: This is, Sir, a Settlement of four hundred per annum upon your eldest lawful begotten Son Richard Addle, out of that Estate lying in the Country of Nullibi, in—

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: Pray read it, Sir, word by word.

sp.speaker: Sir Jo.
sp.p: Faith, Sir, I'm in haste, business calls me speedily hence, and I humbly beg your excuse, I shall warrant it right— pox on the Law, I'm wearied on't already.

sp.speaker: Choll.
sp.p: Very good; no matter; and what's this large Scroll?

sp.speaker: Sir Jo.
sp.p: The honourable Sir Anthony Addle bestows upon his Daughter eight thousand Pounds to be paid the first of January next ensuing.

sp.speaker: Choll.
sp.p: A long term, the first of January next ensuing! Why look ye d'ye see, the Interest of the money at Six per Cent. comes to— ay, let me see, comes to— but no matter, January next, why 'tis a whole year to'r.

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: Body o'me, the Man is in a passion before all these Witnesses: I say Neighbour Chollerick you love not my Daughter.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: No faith, Sir; but your money sets his heart on fire.

sp.speaker: Choll.
sp.p: Well, well, I've done— and what have we got here?

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: This, Sir, contains—

sp.speaker: Choll.
sp.p: What Sir? let me see what does it contain.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Now, Madam, quick relief, or we're all undone.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, 'tis a coming.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Oh, oh, I'm frighted out of my Senses, your Son, Sir—

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: Ay, Body o'me, that's true; where is the young Man?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: O Lord, Sir, Arrested, the Bailiffs have got him, 'tis an Action of Ten thousand pounds: O, Sir, he's almost dead with fear, and e're now he's either in the Spunging-house, or the Counter.

sp.speaker: Choll.
sp.p: Look ye now, look ye now, d'ye see, he has play'd some Rogue's trick, and now he's catcht.

sp.speaker: Sir Jo.
sp.p: This works rarely.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Thank ye, Madam.

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: I say, Neighbour, you are— but no matter— a Rogue's trick!

sp.speaker: Choll.
sp.p: Well, well, I've done; no more on't; let's run and Bail him.

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: By all means, 'twas well mov'd; sincerely 'twas an unlucky accident.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.p: Stop 'em, stop 'em; now's your time to have the Papers subscrib'd.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Stay, Gentlemen, stay; first put your Hands and Seals to these Papers; you know we have much business, and can't wait your return.

sp.speaker: Choll.
sp.p: That's right, one thing shou'd be done before another: which is mine?

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: This, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Jo.
sp.p: Both these are yours.

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: Now all's done, let's run, Neighbour, for my Son's relief: the delivery of the Papers is forgot; but no matter, we'll do't when we come back.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.p: Now, Gentlemen, play your game well; the Stakes lye ready before ye, and here are no old Bullies to sweep the Table.

sp.speaker: Sir Jo.
sp.p: Well, Ladies, you see the Common danger (for such I hope you'll own it) our good Fortune has allow'd this Critical minute for us all: which, if well imploy'd, brings a continu'd happiness— we've been good Counsellors too.

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: Now, Revenge, Love, and Liberty call aloud: sure such powerful musick must affect the heart, and set the soul afloat.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: Come, Gentlemen, Ceremonies are now dangerous, because tedious; I'm fairly resolv'd to go with ye.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: And I.

div.stage: [They run off, Mel. Tim. Sir John and Ned, Decoy following.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: You'll stay behind I suppose, Madam?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Why faith, Captain, I doubt whether I shall or not.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: If you do, Madam, then I must sleep a Batchellor to night.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: No, hang it, that's a dull comfortless life; I'll rather try the Fool's Paradise, and for once be married.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: That's well thought of; the Gentleman in Black, I suppose, has conjur'd Sir John already half way into the Circle; let us succeed, and get the second or third cast of his Office.

div.stage: Enter Sir Anth. Choll. and Dick.

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: Body o'me, the Rogues shall be severely punish'd; why, they had not a Writ against the Young-man.

sp.speaker: Dick.
sp.p: By Ovid I'm sick, the Rogues have frighted me so, I shan't be able to show my self a man to night again.

sp.speaker: Choll.
sp.p: Villains, Vagabonds, Rakes, Rascals, Sons of— God forgive me, they had almost spoil'd our mirth; Rogues—

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: Sincerely 'tis no matter, all's well again: now to our business— ha! where are the Lawyers?— gone— hoa? who waits there?

div.p: Where are the Lawyers? the Parson? and my Daughters?

sp.speaker: Choll.
sp.p: And my Niece; my Niece I ask?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: All gone abroad, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: Body o'me! we're betray'd, cheated, ruin'd, and undone.

sp.speaker: Dick.
sp.p: Pox on your House-keepers Lawyers, I say.

sp.speaker: Choll.
sp.p: 'Tis rare work, and Ned has a hand in't; that young Dog must have a finger in the pye; I'll have him hang'd; I'll have him hang'd, Tyburn is too good for the Rogue— O that Villain!

sp.speaker: Dick.
sp.p: By Jupiter I'm finely serv'd, I've lost my Supper, just when my Appetite had taught me to long for it.

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: Run, Sirrah, run; cry, stop the Thieves, the Murderers, the Robbers, the any-things, body o'me, all's lost.

div.stage: Enter Sir John, Captain Ned, Mel. Flo. and Tim.

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: No Sir, 'tis not lost, that is on a friend bestow'd.

sp.speaker: Choll.
sp.p: So, Sirrah; I knew the Rogue was one at this mischief; I knew't you dog you, I'll make you— let me come at him— this Case and his Shoulders must renew their acquaintance.

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: Body o'me, we have entertain'd Wolves in Sheeps-cloathing.

sp.speaker: Dick.
sp.p: By Jupiter, two of them were in Fox's Cloathing: but uds so, I hope they are not married, Sir-father.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: Thus low I kneel to beg your Blessing: this Gentleman is your Son, and my Husband.

sp.speaker: Dick.
sp.p: A damn'd confounded Rogue, is he?

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: Body o'me, the young Woman has out-witted me: but since she's married to a Knight's Son, I forgive her; I ever esteem'd your Father Sir Thomas— Rise, Daughter; prove an obedient Wife, and my Blessing shall never be wanting.

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: This sudden Change speaks the goodness of your Nature; nor shall my duty (if possible) ever show it self less than your kindness— this Gentleman too deserves your pardon and esteem.

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: How! body o'me! Flo. married!

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Yes faith, Sir, I long'd to taste the sweet Sin of Rebellion: and now the fact is committed, I want a Remission.

sp.speaker: Dick.
sp.p: Uds so, Sir father; the Jades are all mad.

sp.speaker: Choll.
sp.p: Ned, Sirrah, Rascal, are you really married to this Woman? Durst you use your Unkle thus?— 'Twas a needless question, the graceless Villain wou'd stick at nothing; but I'll be reveng'd, I will, Sirrah; let them all starve.

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: What's past can't be recall'd; the Girl was ne'er (it seems) ordain'd for a Nun, and the method she has pursu'd perswades me she has Wit: I wish you, Sir, all that happiness you desire; may you be envied by none, and esteem'd by all.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: This indeed alone cou'd add to my happiness: your friendship and this young Lady's love exalt me above the reach of Fortune's malice: shou'd she now ●rown, I'd laugh at her weakness; she can give no more, for this mighty gift has exhausted all her treasure.

sp.speaker: Sir Jo.
sp.p: I've presum'd without your Consent to marry your Niece, my—

sp.speaker: Choll.
sp.p: Well, well, Sir, and starve with her when you've done; my Consent was worth nothing: the blessing of a thousand pounds was a meer trifle; the Parson's was enough for you: but no matter, let that buy your Dinner; I'll see you all starve like so many Rats in a ruinous house.

sp.speaker: Sir Jo.
sp.p: No, Sir, this secures me from that plague you threaten.

sp.speaker: Choll.
sp.p: What's that, Sirrah?— I profess I long to swinge this Rogue.

sp.speaker: Sir Jo.
sp.p: Ten thousand pounds Alderman Chollerick gave me with his Niece; I suppose 'twas all her own.

sp.speaker: Choll.
sp.p: Oh Dog! oh Villain! oh Wretch! I'm chous'd! ruin'd! and— but 'tis no matter! I'll be reveng'd; I'll have Law; I'll spend all I have in the recovery of my right, I will— let me come at him—

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: Have patience, Neighbour, body o' me, I begin to think that I'm no better us'd than I shou'd be.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Why faith, Sir, I've made bold with eight thousand pounds instead of that design'd for your Son.

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: And body o' me, I suppose you've been such another Counsellor.

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: Yes, faith, Sir, I presume ye know these Letters to be of your own making.

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: Sinceely speaking, 'tis so; I hope however I've got discrcet Creditors who won't sue a Commission of Bankrupt against me.

sp.speaker: Choll.
sp.p: Look ye Ned; you're a Rogue, a confounded unlucky Villain.

sp.speaker: Dick.
sp.p: Uds so, so he is, and us'd me once very Scurvily; but by Iupiter I dare not complain, lest he renew his kindness.

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: I'm now master of Ten thousand pounds; I remember your old Maxim, Law for Money; and if it hold, you'll add another Ten to't.

sp.speaker: Choll.
sp.p: Look ye now, the Rogue has me already on the sore hip— Ned, Ned, why Ned, I am thy Uncle, and thy best friend; I've a great kindness for thee, and wou'd not willingly put thee to charges: banish, my dear boy Ned, all thoughts of Law, and live happy with thy present fortune.

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: No disputes on a bridal night, the business shall be amicably compos'd at another time.

div.stage: Enter Freelove, and Lucy, Decoy following.

sp.speaker: Choll.
sp.p: Now, now look ye; whom have we here? if he's one of Ned's Companions, he's a Rogue, and she a Jilt.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Gentlemen, I wish you much Joy, and you, fair Ladies; I was inform'd of your good fortunes, and cou'd be no longer absent; I'm happy too, and blest as you are.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: This, Sir, is a Gentleman, and my friend.

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: You're very welcome, Sir; Body o' me, my Son in-Law's friend is no less than a Member of my family, and may confidently claim my Service.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Sir, I'm your very humble Servant.

sp.speaker: Dick.
sp.p: Uds so, he has got a delicate Wench, wou'd I had married her.

sp.speaker: Sir Jo.
sp.p: How long, Freelove, hast thou been acquainted with this young Lady?

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Not above two days; 'twas by Madam Derceys means I had the good fortune to be belov'd, and Marriage soon follow'd.

sp.speaker: Sir Jo.
sp.p: Then, Jack, thou art abus'd, I know her Circumstances, and can assure thee she is not Mistress of a hundred pounds.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Kind heaven bless me with the gift of patience, I m ruin'd, Fortune has done her worst; and in betraying others, I've undone my self.

sp.speaker: Sir Jo.
sp.p: Thou too art cheated; but to salve this sore, I'le give thee a thousand pounds, and one hundred yearly during thy 〈◊〉: forget Sir John 〈◊〉 and the follies of thy younger years; be Just to thy husband, and in so doing thou art kind to thy self and me— in the mean time, Madam Decoy has us'd you unkindly.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: She has my Bond too for a thousand pounds.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: By heaven, and mine too.

sp.speaker: Sir Jo.
sp.p: These Bonds, Madam, won't be allow'd of by a Judge; and to evite further trouble, 'tis fitting you shou'd restore them.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.p: O dear Sir, two thousand pounds! I deserve them very well.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: The Pillory you mean, Madam.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.p: Truly, Sir, I scorn your words; I'm an honest Woman, and won't be so abus'd, I do every thing above board, and— and—

sp.speaker: Sir Jo.
sp.p: You did assist me in my Love, and therefore I'm your friend; give up the Bonds, and I'll give you a Bill of fifty pounds upon my Goldsmith in Cheapside.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.p: Well, Sir, my duty binds me to obedience; and rather than lose your friendship, I'll do't.

div.stage: [Gives the Bonds, and they tare off their Names.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Come away me Jo, be me Saul we sall be aus merry aus fifty beggars aut au fair; this letter will gau● me new Maister loup out o' his skin for faunness, baut speak o' the meekle deel, aun yer be sure to staurt him— hea Sir, read th●ut, aun see whaut it says tea ye yer aul Aunt is aus deed aus au herring, aun hes left ye au her geer.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: Well, Sir John, I hope you'll remember me now I'm marry'd.

sp.speaker: Sir Jo.
sp.p: Are you her husband? Sirrah?

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: A goad am I Sirrah, thea English men hea na breeding, shame fau me gin they sou'd na gang to Holland to learn it.— But whaut a vengeance is the matter we me Maister, has the aul wutch geen him the wraung sow be the lug, I woner?

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: It is so, good and bad news come together.

sp.speaker: Sir Jo.
sp.p: Then Fortune is Just; thou art not, Jack, beholding to thy wife for all, for now thou hast brought thy share— now Joy shall shine in every face, and Musick shall elevate the Soul to mirth; let the thoughts of business for a while be suspended, and Love the only end of all our actions.

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: Then body o' me Mr. Chorus shall give us a Song: Dick call him in presently.

sp.speaker: Dick.
sp.p: Uds so, Sir-father, I'll sing a Song first, I learn't it of my Landlady's daughter at the Swan, who had the Child by young Hobs the Carrier.

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: With all my heart boy; Sincerely I'm glad to see thee so merry.

sp.speaker: Choll.
sp.p: Rogues, Villains, they will be all hang'd

sp.speaker: Dick.
sp.p: Hem, hem, by Jupiter I have a very good pipe upon occasion.

div.p: Now, Sir-father, how d'ye like it? by Apollo I sung it very well.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: I wull gee au Scotlaun Dance worth fourty o't, baut I waunt a piper.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: The Violin, Sirrah, is better.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Play up thaun Fidlers, aun be haung't tea ye, aut let me hea au ●erray bonny Spring.

div.p: Now me bonny lauds whaut think o't— be me Saul I waunt me Supper; ●ea ye neathing amaung ye tea eet? wa in Scotlaun we eet aun drink three days au on e●, tea mauke us able to please the Bride aun au her Maidens.

sp.speaker: Sir Jo.
sp.p: Now let's have another Song.

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: And as that ends, let the Dance begin.

div.p: Now, Gentlemen, let's take another Road to Pleasure, change the Scene of mirth, and in the next Room (larger than this, and fitted for the purpose) toss a Eumper.

sp.speaker: Dick.
sp.p: Uds so.

q.l: Wine pleasure brings, and Care destroys,
It new creates the Soul for Joys; Ta-la-ra, ta tal fa-la.

div.p: I've lost my Mistress; but by Jupiter I'm not one to be merry.

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: Body o' me, thou'rt in the right Boy— Come, Neighbour Chollerick, forget and forgive, as the saying is: Sincerely, who knows but I may live to get another Daughter for ye?

sp.speaker: Choll.
sp.p: No matter, let Ned, and that Jilt be hang'd; let the rest of the Rogues be— But stay; I will drink with them before I go.

div.stage: [Is running off in a passion, and returns suddenly.

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: Then, Gentlemen, let's go in.

sp.speaker: Sir Jo.
sp.p: This day has repair'd all our Sufferings past, and we may safely now, without vanity, believe our selves belov'd, if Youth (e're Judgment● strong) knew all the Joys, the true content, and peace of mind, which honest Love rewarded can bestow, they'd envy our happiness, and contemn that uncertain state of life, which instead of pleasure, gives continued pains.

q.l: Love and Ambition, something are a-kin;
But mighty Love is still the nobler Sin;
It wakes the sleeping Soul, and makes it still
Seek greater Goods than purblind Reason will.
We covet nothing, when we all possess;
Our Joys wax greater, and our Fears grow less;
And lasting Pleasures with our Years encrease.

div.head: EPILOGUE:
Spoke by WILL. PINKETHMAN.
div.l: YOur Favour's the Reward, I and the Author—
O, stay, no—
The Author and I do jointly seek it;
He finds the Wit, and I— the face to speak it:
And that we may succeed in our Design,
I come to Court you— arm'd with Wit and Wine.
The Fair alone from this Device will shrink;
For as they never Hiss, they never Drink
— in Publick:
Yet these are th' terms (the Author's such a Fop)
If you don't Hiss— I must not Taste a drop.
Then, Friendly Sirs, be to your Servant just,
And Damn the Epilogue to Quench my Thirst.
〈…〉 Fulness so wou'd mutter,
I shou'd not take a Bottle after Supper—
What not yet, are all against me bent?
Egad, I'll take your Silence for Consent.
— I dare not venture:
O, so— very well—
very well:
Nay! Now once more—
Will. Pinkethman begs you to be Civil;
To have Wine by one, and not drink's, the Devil.
You're all Good-natur'd if you're Cross to night,
And you'll oblige your humble Servant by't;
For tho' the Wit is Counterfeit, the Wine is right.
But now for the Epilogue— Egad this is not the
Paper! What shall I do! Let me see if I can
remember it— Ha! hum! No; well
I'll speak one of my Own.—
But now I think on't, his is very Pretty;
And I'm afraid I shan't be half so Witty:
So if you'll stay till I go find the right,
I'll read it now— Else call to morrow night.
But hold!
I've something now of Consequence to say,
Good simple Bays on me bestows his Play;
Therefore, dear Friends, come all on the Third Day.
If not to him, to me your Favour show,
And think on poor Will Pinkethman; for you must know,
Your Long Vacations make him very Low.
And now the Fatal time is Drawing on,
When you will all Forsake this Charming Town,
And to the Country for Diversion run.
The Gamesters, They to Epsom take their way;
And while they are with the City-Dames at play,
The Husband's Bowl their Coin and Cares away.
The Masks (Alas, poor Souls!) they must stay here,
And to the Folly will in Sholes repair,
To feed on Cold stufft Beef, and drink stale Beer.
The Players; ay, they're left too in the Lurch;
Why, they must e'en go twice a Day to Church:
For since they're like to live upon the Air,
'Tis fit their Fasting shou'd be joyn'd with Pray'r.
